pr_title: Validates the file path of a TexGroup and fixes Texgroup's "Library has been modified by another program"

timeline.message: process GROUPSTREE and GROUPSTREE_LEGACY at the very end
validator for aux file added, checking for empty field and using the validationVisualizer
formatting file according to JabRef's formatter for Eclipse

Revert "formatting file according to JabRef's formatter for Eclipse"

This reverts commit ad11243bb1e29bcaae6caa8fdd41b728844f1282.

timeline.author: calixtus

timeline.bodyText:
Please avoid simple whitespace changes. Eclipse tends to push lines beyond 80 characters just to line method arguments with the brackets. But this makes it hard to read on smaller screens as well as in code reviews.
Also we want to avoid an 'IDE war' in JabRef, since autoformat in IntelliJ would then put a tabspace there instead again with the next refactor. We try to keep a consistent codestyle in JabRef and common practice is now to use the IntelliJ-style, as it keeps the code more compact.
timeline.author: calixtus
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -117,103 +119,113 @@ public GroupDialogViewModel(DialogService dialogService, BibDatabaseContext curr
 
     private void setupValidation() {
         nameValidator = new FunctionBasedValidator<>(
-                nameProperty,
-                StringUtil::isNotBlank,
-                ValidationMessage.error(Localization.lang("Please enter a name for the group.")));
+                                                     nameProperty,

timeline.bodyText: Please omit the underscore in variable names.
timeline.author: calixtus

timeline.bodyText: I think this check can be reduced to StringUtil.isBlank().
timeline.author: calixtus

timeline.bodyText: Can you please use more meaningful variable names? Like entrySetStream and groupsTreeStream or similar.
timeline.author: calixtus

timeline.bodyText: The english here sounds a bit rough. I myself often use deepl.com to produce texts, since english isn't my mother tongue. There's no shame in that. 😉
timeline.author: calixtus
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -83,6 +83,8 @@ Note that this project **does not** adhere to [Semantic Versioning](http://semve
 - We fixed an issue where "null" appeared in generated BibTeX keys. [#6459](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/6459)
 - We fixed an issue where the authors' names were incorrectly displayed in the authors' column when they were bracketed. [#6465](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/6465) [#6459](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/6459)
 - We fixed an issue where importing certain unlinked files would result in an exception [#5815](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/5815)
+- We fixed an issue with creating a group of cited entries, which wrongly triggered that the library had been changed externally. [#6420](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/6420)

timeline.author: calixtus
calixtus

replies.bodyText: I'm not sure, whether this is a good idea. I intended to explicitly check the provided file, without searching other locations. 🤔
replies.author: systemoperator
calixtus

timeline.bodyText: This can probably abbreviated with FileUtil.getFileExtension()
timeline.author: calixtus

timeline.bodyText: I think sorting the entries as described here https://stackoverflow.com/a/30286728/873661 is a bit more readable.
timeline.author: tobiasdiez

timeline.bodyText: A more "streamy" way is using the stream.foreach(...) method.
timeline.author: tobiasdiez

replies.bodyText: In the loop exceptions may be thrown. It's slightly complicated to throw them back within a lambda expression (at least for me).
replies.author: systemoperator

replies.bodyText: ok, good argument. I think first using collect to get an ordinary list and then using foreach is still slightly better.
replies.author: tobiasdiez

timeline.bodyText: Just an idea: Can creating streams theoretically be omitted by using List.copyof(data.entrySet()).sort(groupsLast()) ?
timeline.author: calixtus

timeline.bodyText: I would suggest removing empty @throws annotations.
timeline.author: koppor
koppor

timeline.bodyText:
Can we keep the switch (entry.getKey) somehow? Maybe nested in an else branch?
You can use the new Java14 switch: https://openjdk.java.net/jeps/361
(File needs to be added to 
  
    
      jabref/config/checkstyle/checkstyle.xml
    
    
         Line 15
      in
      ca06b71
    
    
    
    

        
          
           <property name="fileNamePattern" value="AuthorAndsReplacer.java|Ordinal.java|EntryTypeView.java" /> 
        
    
  

 then)
timeline.author: koppor

replies.bodyText:
This is still a huge p.i.t.a.
Checkstyle really needs to keep up, people start getting tired of these workarounds.
Some background information, if you are interested: checkstyle/checkstyle#6615
replies.author: calixtus

replies.bodyText: The key problem is here that switch cases are not executed in order. That's the reason for the if else
replies.author: Siedlerchr

replies.bodyText:
In the concrete case here, it is always checked for entry.getKey(). Please check the diff:

The wrong order was at that diff - completely unrelated to my proposal!
replies.author: koppor

replies.bodyText: Yes, the switch statement could be reintroduced (and simplified). Before this fix, the code was structured really confusing and looked error-prone. So I decided to create this consistent and simplified version, which I find quite acceptable.
replies.author: systemoperator

replies.bodyText:
I meant only for the lower part; not with the xxxx continue statements. Just for the endless chain of else if (entry.getKey().equeals(MetaData.X)) chains, where only X is different from the checks.
There is ALWAYS entry.getKey() compared from line 75 to line 92 (or did I see something wrong?).
This is just a matter of taste. Maybe, I'll just do it and open another PR to have the discussions there. Should not be a show stopper for us now.
replies.author: koppor
